questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the ED after his grandmother witnessed him inserting a small toy marble into his right ear 3 hours ago. The child is alert and cooperative but reports his ear feels “stuffed.” Otoscopy shows a smooth, spherical object at the inner end of the cartilaginous canal with an intact tympanic membrane. An initial attempt at removal using alligator forceps results in the marble moving deeper toward the isthmus. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Irrigate the ear canal with saline using a 20-mL syringe
Attempt removal using a balloon-tipped catheter
Reattempt removal with forceps after procedural sedation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Irrigation with a 20-mL syringe is appropriate for many foreign bodies, but the marble has already moved deeper with one removal attempt, creating high risk for further displacement toward the tympanic membrane during irrigation.

B) INCORRECT:

The balloon-tipped catheter technique requires passing the catheter behind the foreign body and inflating before retraction. As the unsuccessful initial attempt resulted in deeper migration, this technique poses significant risk of pushing the object further or causing canal trauma.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- ENT consultation is indicated for unsuccessful removal attempts. An unsuccessful initial attempt with apparent deeper migration creates risk for canal trauma or tympanic membrane injury with further attempts in the ED.

D) INCORRECT:

Cyanoacrylate-tipped applicators require patient cooperation and may not be appropriate for children. This technique carries risk of leaving additional foreign material in the ear and is not appropriate after an unsuccessful removal attempt.

E) INCORRECT:

Procedural sedation is itself an indication for ENT consultation rather than a reason to reattempt removal in the ED. The risk of canal or tympanic membrane injury remains high regardless of sedation status.
